comment: Spicy; caramel apple pound cake; goes bitter on the finish before becoming sweet baking spices
Notes of orange, vanilla and coconut on the nose.  On the palate, spice and vanilla.  A long oaky and satisfying finish.
For the money, RR store picks are incredible. Worth every $$$. This one is a little sweet and ends with a cherry taste. Wow. Too bad I only grabbed one bottle.

Neat.  Hitting me right tonight.  Great nose.    Sweet corn with vanilla and apricot.  Nice oily texture.  Get some nice sugar on the tongue.  More fruit flavors on the taste, berries and cream.  Gives ways to a punch of spice.  Cinnamon, pepper.  Lingers with a nice long finish.  Either this opened up or my taste gravitated towards this, but I am adoring this at the moment.

Wow, for 110 proof you only get one quick punch of alcohol. This is a fantastic creamy tasting bourbon with a subtle nose that is less harsh than others I've had between 100-120 proof. It is a little pricy but I highly recommend for a special occasion. I was originally going to get something like Baker's or a name brand cask strength, and I'm so glad I went with this instead. At 110 proof this is basically a cask strength anyways since most are between 110-130 proof. I'm anxious to try Rare Breed next and compare the two.

Update - I've had this open for nearly 2 months and it has mellowed out. The nose is really soft now, but it is so drinkable. If I didn't know the proof I'd say it was 95-100. I barely get any alcohol burn even with swishing around my mouth. This is a fantastic bourbon.
Smooth on the front end with a bite on the back end. Not a bad sipping bourbon.

Local store pick
17-925. H. 4th floor
Nose:
Astringent alcohol
Light brown sugar 
Vanilla 
Touch of oak char
Palate:
Red hots
Cinnamon 
Warming spice 
Touch of sweetness 
Finish:

Dry oak
Sweetness

Cinnamony spice. Smooth. Good flavor. Not a lot of burn. Not sure about value though since it was a gift. Would definitely buy in the $40 range. Above that would be a solid maybe. A probably not in the sixties.
Very good stuff. Nice long finish.

Nose: caramel, toffee
Palate: med-full richness, quick hit of spice and burn
Finish: burn calms down, plenty of all spice. Opens up with the spice still present and flattening out. Very good.

Barrel 17-0669
Rickhouse D
Floor 6 2 1
Gordon’s private barrel store pick 
Bottled May 2018
Color is deep amber. Nose is fairly weak but complex, with faint vanilla, caramel, bubble gum and cinnamon apple pie. Velvety mouth feel. Palate is well balanced, with cinnamon and clove with hints of vanilla. Finish also a bit weak, lingering oak with subtle spice but without much character or depth. Some alcohol burn in the mouth, but not much of a hug. I do like this one as a daily sipper, but disappointing for the price and reputation.
Delicious! Hits you fast and furious up front and then a long slow and smooth finish of smokey barrel, almonds/bits, and cinnamon. Slow easy sipper that is easy to enjoy.
Fantastic bourbon! Smooth, flavorful, a little heat at the end. Might be one of my favorites so far!

Nose: candy corn, dusty oak, dark fruits

Palate: rich, sweet up front then becomes drier, nutmeg and clove, citrus and a little iced tea underneath the spices 

Finish: medium and a bit warm, rye shines more on this than standard Wild Turkey offerings 

Delicate and rich, this is a creamier and more complex Wild Turkey that I think most bourbon lovers can appreciate.
Spicy caramel with a little oak. Short finish, but good flavors.

Mild nose. 
Sharp sweet carmel and spice.  
Very nice.
I like this. Smooth and tasty.
it gets better with every sip.
Vanilla, caramel and oak. Nice spicy finish. One of my favorites.
Friar Tuck store pick! Definitely getting the baking spices and apple pie note. Also vanilla & cinnamon with slight coconut macaroon! Lots of delicious layers in this whiskey
Fine but nothing exciting to me. Maybe I just got a bad single barrel. Long finish, just not as much flavor. To me I kind of get a cherry or cough syrup. Not for me
Very fragrant, with a cherry-dominant nose. Lots of dark cherries on the tongue, with notes of caramel, red wine, and subtle vanilla. Heat is there, but isn't super aggressive. Excellent.
Very smooth with a small bite in the finish but for 110 proof not bad.

Not bad for the price. Little vanilla in the nose. Heat at the start through finish that overwhelms the other flavors, definitely not tasting the vanilla others noted, might be the barrel. Would likely mix well. Tried it neat.
Great nose with caramel and oak. Taste has nice spicy rye kick with a great finish. Love the oily mouth feel.
Single barrel excellence. Nose vanilla, toffee, and oak. Taste oak, tobacco, leather, and baking spices. Very good bourbon.
Single barrel Rye, fantastic! Spicy, rye, Caramel and oak. Very very good bourbon

The epitome of WT, especially if you can purchase store picked barrels. Phenomenal nose of oak, spice and vanilla frosting. On the palate it luscious and layered. Upfront you’ve got the baking spice and immediately thereafter the wonderful oak and sweetness kicks in. Leading to a medium to long finish. Truly a terrific bourbon to enjoy slowly and take it all in. Cheers!
Smooth and flavorful with just the right amount of burn. Several layers of rich flavors including cinnamon and vanilla. A nice sipping whiskey even at 110 proof.

Starts with slightly salted caramel with hints of nutmeg and cloves. Finishes warm with notes of tobacco and leather. A splash of distilled water brings out the fruits dates and raisins. Very complex single barrel! This was a barrel select at Total Wine
Spicy. A solid higher proof SiB. Would drink on the reg!
My local store Discount Drinks store pick. Becoming a favorite of mine.

Ohio Father’s Day single barrel select program.

Look: dark amber/brown.

Smell: I don’t get much on this one- the alcohol is evident. Lots of oak but when I sniff any deeper my nose hairs get singed.

Taste: hot damn this is good. Cinnamon, oak, tobacco, cocoa. 55% is noticeable but there is relatively little burn. A little bit of water brings out brown sugar/molasses, apples and vanilla. 

This is a happy medium for me between the barrel proof bourbons and the lower alcohol bottles. Definitely worth the money if you can get it at msrp
Smooth to start with a nice spicy finish. Notes of vanilla and pepper throughout.
-Part of the Distiller Top Single Barrels under $100-

Barrel 17-342, rickhouse B, floor 6 59 1.  

N:  Typical Wild Turkey oaken cinnamon nutmeg blend and brown sugar burst, while maple and toffee follow closely behind with a bit of herbal mint.

P:  Cinnamon, vanilla, brown sugar, toffee, maple, nutmeg, and hints of mint.

F: Toasted oak, nutmeg, anise.

I enjoyed this quite a bit.  It checks just about all of the boxes.  It blends sweetness and spice together very well.  It packs heavy doses of maple and toffee. The Russell Reserves are usually very good, and this is no exception.  Rickhouse B has a reputation for churning out some fantastic single barrel’s.  While this does fall short of fantastic; it does qualify as very good.

Neat.  Gallenstein 16 pick.  Nose is so well balanced.  Caramel and barrel spice gives way to vanilla and a floral/mint note.  Simultaneously gives you light and dark notes on the nose.  Very thick mouth feel.  Oak and brown sugar swarm the palate.  Gives way to chocolate with a slight hint of vanilla on the nose.  That is top notch.
Store Pick. touch of vanilla, caramel, and spice on the nose. Taste of light caramel and oak, moderate baking spices, faint vanilla
This is beautiful. All the turkey goodness dialed up to 11. Smooth, strong, sweet, spicy, and so easy to drink.
Spicy. Fun to drink. Lots of flavor. Okay finish. Would buy this again.
Very strong initially but aftertaste is smokey and smooth.
Like WT101 but smoother. I just finished a Virginia ABC sore pick and it was solidly one of my top 5 favorite pours. Excellent bourbon.
Great tasting bourbon for a good price. This bourbon drinks as good as the wild turkey master’s series imo... Very similar profiles. No need to spend the extra money.
Lots of spice with a smooth vanilla and caramel aftertaste. Great color.

Nose: cherry Vanilla Coke. 

Palate: cherry bomb. Sooo good. Reminds me of a thicker Evan Williams SiB. 

Finish : medium/short cherries

Interesting pour for sure. Hot on the front end, heavy oak, cinnamon candy. Quickly rolls into vanilla and orange and then a long apple pie spice finish. Typically I lean towards a high rye mash bill but definitely enjoying this WT bottle.
Easily the best bourbon I’ve tasted. Strong and spicy with vanilla and caramel flavors. Great neat or with a few cubes of ice.

I picked up a barrel pick for the Triad Municipal ABC board (NC) about a month ago. Tried it neat and it was hot. The ethanol and spice flushed out any other flavors. Tried it a few more times and got the same experience. Tried it with a little water and it did cut the spice but the other traditional bourbon flavors are still masked by the spice. I’m a huge fan of barrel proof / high proof bourbons, but this doesn’t hold a candle to Blanton’s SFTB, Woodford Batch Proof or Elijah Craig Barrel Proof or Weller 107. Do not agree at all with the 95 score this has, but to each his own. I’ll save this for nights when I cheat on keto and decide to drink an old fashion.

Color: Honey
Nose: Slight ethanol, maybe a Lilith flowery, brown sugar butter
Palate: Spicy, Lille bit of baked bread and honey
Finish: Light burn, corn
Rating: 6/10

Tasting the store pick "Blackout" from the Rural Inn in Indianapolis.

N: sweet, caramel and maple syrup, hints of raspberry and rye...almost like a spicy Capri-sun???, herbal notes of honeysuckle and mint. A few drops of water brings out malt and cocoa

P: very woody - fresh oak, and walnuts, dark chocolate and cinnamon mid palate with hints of mint throughout.

F: hotter than expected, but bitter chocolate and wood notes linger with pepper flavors that last a loooooooong time. This one lingers!

Very interesting, complex flavors. Not for casual drinking unless diluted slightly or in a cocktail. But a wonderful flavor profile and a finish lasting for ever.
Smooth and vanilla for the high proof
Best bourbon I’ve had. Really smooth with hints of fruit amongst many other flavors. Exceptional bourbon.
Slightly sharp taste, especially at first. Smooths out in the aftertaste. Bit of burn going down
Sharp alcohol taste but smooth smell and really round, full finish. There’s a lot going on here but it’s burned out by the alcohol. Adding water didn’t really help, the alcohol is still too sharp.
Hits you in the back of the throat, nice and complex finish
Oak and vanilla aroma. Vanilla, oak, and spices. Viscous mouthfeel.

Oak & Cedar Society 2019 Commish

19-0174 - A - Floor 4 

Cinnamon spicy up front leads to smooth vanilla
750ml poured neat in a rocks glass at B Side in Merrifield, VA.  Nose is mild, with apple peel, lite grass. Taste has spice, oak, hay.  Finish has lingering spice. This is good.  7/3/19
Wow, first sip wow’d me. Very tasty. A new staple in my collection.
Hot taste with initial alcohol burn. A hot finish.
Little bitter, could not find melted marshmallow

Nose is baking bread, funky yeast, cinnamon, rye, caramel, apple, cinnamon.
Apples and spice, barrel char.  Caramel.  Rye spice, some funky yeasty flavor.  Very buttery, buttercream icing.

55%, so lots of ethanol on the nose. I smelled dark, ripe strawberry. Not quite as rich as cherry or plum, but dark red fruit. On the taste, light cinnamon, not heavy on the vanilla or oak, which is refreshing. Much more rich dark fruit than most bourbons. Reminds me of Angel’s Envy, but obviously not finished in port barrels. Excellent bourbon, good complexity, but not as rich in mouthfeel or finish as Garrison Brothers or Weller Antique.
Rich sweet with long finish bit of spice small bite
Strong tasting bourbon, not smooth at all.  Doesn't have any offensive flavors, but it does burn.

A good dram, especially if you like high proof Bourbons.  Having said that, of the two Russell"s Bourbons, I have a preference for the 10 over this one.  There's just a slight bitter note on the palate and the finish of the Single Barrell.  It doesn't feel out of place, nor does it overwhelm the other flavors.  But it's not my thing  I suspect that the bitter note comes from the rye in the mashbill; rye lovers may well be drawn to it.  The 10 is more mellow, but still has many of same nice notes as the Single Barrell.
Vanilla, caramel, deep/rich, nice char notes, similar to 4Roses SiB.
Hot leading in followed quickly by atomic fire ball that fades into a vanilla moon pie. I like it!

Costco store pick
So much flavor and aroma!
Nose  Wood, butterscotch, cinnamon, vanilla
Taste  cinnamon, spicy, chocolate in finish, creme brûlée, almond
Long finish
Oak and spice taste. Good finish with sugar and honey

Taste: 1.5 oz. pour (×3!) Neat in glen cairn.  Binnys pick #19-00035, floor 4, Rick CN A

Nose (5):  Juicy fruit gum, cherries, baking spices and just enough ethanol to let you know this is serious.

Palate (5):  orchard fruit basket, dark plums, red apples, carmel over vanilla nougat.  So juicy and vibrant it is like "fresh squeezed."  

Finish (5) :  Hint of fresh squeezed pear juice followed by a spicy cinnamon finish.  The Juicy Fruit gum on the nose then lingers for a long after effect.

Overall: This is a bourbon that reminds me of why I like bourbon!  So well balanced, so many good flavors together in cohesion.  It is easy to drink, easy to like, and at 59.99 a no brainer.  I have had 5 different Russell's SiB picks in the past 3 years.  This one is absolutely the best so far.
High proof but very high quality. Can drink straight even at this proof. Very good.

Nose is full of toffee. First sip is sweet toffee followed by oak. Strong spicy finish, as is to be expected at 110 proof. Adding a few drops of water smooths out the mouthfeel and opens up notes of vanilla and cinnamon. Overall, once you get accustomed to the high proof to the flavor, this is an excellent Bourbon. However, given the price, this probably will not be your everyday Bourbon.

ABC store pick barrel 16-339 

Rickhouse K

Floor 5-45-2
I keep going back to the single barrels that I find. Just one of the best all around bourbon's on the market.
Good flavor with a little bite at the end

Store pick: galenstein #10
Nose: cinnamon, ethanol, dill, oak, unripe banana 
Palate: licorice, leather, honey, barrel char
Finish: long, brown sugar, cinnamon, pepper
Store pick from Off Premise. This is just a friggin excellent pour. A great mix of spicy and sweet with just the right amount of bite

This is a store pick from Woodland Wine Merchant in Nashville, TN.  They included all of the Barrel and rickhouse info, but I’ll omit that for now.

On the nose I get brown sugar, a little vanilla, cherries, leather, a hint of some dark fruit and baking spices.

The palate has a few things going on and takes a minute to separate the flavors. There isn’t one that pokes out over the others really.
I get some leather, oak, and dark fruit. Not really that sweet. 

The finish is the short side of long. No burn really. Just a slight minty aftertaste.

I like this one. Not really overly complex, but it hits on areas that I enjoy. Though I wished it had some louder notes.

OK so this is a store pick, but it's a single barrel product so how special can a store pick even be?  

55%rickhouse CNF and Floor 641.  Good info and I know the turkey fans will know just which rickhouse that is and will even know which notes they'd expect from me.  For me, I'm a bit disappointed we don't get age detail.

Nose - So there's a hair of wood funk to go with our traditional bourbon notes of oak, caramel, and vanilla.  I get a touch of finger nail polish remover.  I get a touch of cherry.  There's a lot of alcohol on here, far more than 55% should indicate.  Overall a nice pleasant all bit it a bit alcohol forward nose.  Not overly complex but not boring.  I like the cherry note on the finish and that bit of oak funk it a nice switch up.

Taste - Not a nice way to start this but it's hot on the tongue, really overly alcohol, rare breads don't have this much alcohol for me.  So get some of the fruity cherry note but it gets hit with some off note as a swallow, it's some bad oak and just crazy astringent, it's bitter, and wow the finish is just an alcohol burnt mouth.  Water certainly does help, it brings in some nutty character but it doesn't mask the off notes, it does curb the alcohol.  Yeah bitter oak and it's really keeping me from even getting into the nice bourbon notes under it.  

I'm really disappointed in this bottle.  There's just no shaking that it's not good whisky.  Hopefully, I'll get to try a better bottle and I'll put a new review up.  For now I'm going with 0.5 as the nose is actually nice enough and I enjoy smelling it.

Leaving it at a 4.5 to leave room for others, but this is the best bourbon I’ve had yet (granted I’ve not tried many).

Depth of flavor, richness, some vanilla on the nose and palate, wood - like a stand of ponderosa pine - oak barrel comes through a bit, a little funky smoke or some such.

Loses some of its character when mixed or diluted, much better neat.
Great bourbon, flavor has complexity. A little bit of bite up front but after a couple of sips it smooths out on the palate. I think the expert review is a bit high but it’s very good.

Clear Dark amber 
Sweet/Carmel nose
Leathery beginning

Local store pick I grabbed. 

Really cool whiskey. Tobacco, leather, peanuts, brown sugar and cherry coke on the nose. 

Leather, sugary pecans and a citrusy finish. Cool dram. Excited to taste this again at the end of the bottle.

Very sweet on the nose. It starts with sweet fruit and leads into brown sugar and vanilla. The finish goes from sweetness to rye spice. This bourbon does not disappoint! Lots of flavor and surprisingly mild at 110 proof. This was a Total Wine barrel select.
Bold nose and taste. Good balance of spice, oak, and vanilla.

On first taste this burns with a feeling much higher than its proof. The second taste gave me notes of cherry, almost thick and sweet on the tongue like maraschino liqueur.  Later sips brought more of the spices in play.  Good but not top tier for the $70 price tag.  Barrel selection for Southern Spirits.
Barrel 18-0314 Rickhouse A Floor 04 04 02. Discount Drinks pick. Holy cinnamon Batman!
Light sweetness, Woody. Compared with old Forrester birthday, roughly equivalent

Sweet nose of white chocolate, corn, coconut, caramel, charred oak, and banana that finishes with rye spice and cinnamon. 

Palate is more spice forward with nice lingering carmel, coconut, and white chocolate with nice viscosity and roundness in the mouth and good warmth, without too much burn for 55%.

Honestly this is one of my favorites. I can find it most of the time and the price point isn't too bad for a single barrel.

Company Burger Barrel Pick
$7/pour at Barrel Proof

My oh my. It's basically Diet Stagg Jr.  Just a little less sweeter and a bit more spicy than Stagg Jr, but still very very good. If you're needin a fixin for the junya, this is the closest you'll get. So so good.

Nose - coconut, green apple, strong alcohol, floral

Taste - pepper, spice, caramel, very warming

Much better after a drop of water
Vanilla, oak, and spice aroma. Vanilla, maple, and oak with cinnamon and other spices.

RR10: 👃 Woody citrus orange peel
oily spicy oaky black pepper

This particular bottle was a Total Wine barrel pick with Eddie Russel himself.  Ran about $5 more than the shelf bottles so it was a no brainer.

The nose makes me think wood burning fireplace meets boozy, zesty fruitcake with toasted nuts and dried fruit.  The nose is rich and warming, like steam coming off of maple syrup and pancakes.

This is smooth as can be on the front with burn on the back that relaxes to a long, playful finish.  There is a lot of sweet vanilla up front and cinnamon and nutmeg in the back with oak and orange peel.  

Every step is an experience that transports me to a crisp fall day.  Somehow I’m warm on the inside with a mouth and nose bursting with excitement that rolls from one flavor to the next and back again.

Pricy but 100% worth it.  This is a bottle I will miss.

** Store Pick - The Well, OKC**
Possibly my favorite Bourbon when factoring price in the mix. This is a big experience of the senses. The nose was full of cinnamon, vanilla, char and even ripe berries. The palette was a repeat of the aromas in a silky smooth mouthfeel with an extremely long finish.

Look... there are so many retailers jumping on this stuff putting ridiculous cartoon stickers and slap stick names on these bottles. Bottom line up front, it’s F’n good stuff and it doesn’t have to have some nonsense nickname to prove it. Let the idiot taters on the secondary market seek out the “exclusive” bottles and the rest of us can scoop up all the great RR left behind.
Little fruity with a dark finish
This a classic example of bourbon. It hits all of the right notes the alcohol heat the vanilla and oak with hints of chocolate and a long finish.
Honey goodness from start to finish

Nose: citrus oak cinnamon vanilla honey   Nicely complex
Palate: citrus and oak
Body: decent but would like more texture and body
Finish: nice spice but like a longer build to the peak
Balance: definitely a strong suit   Nicely tied together and complex

Final number: 92.5

Unmistakably Wild Turkey heritage.  Vanilla, oak, boiled peanuts, spice on the nose gives way to toffee, vanilla, oak char, more spice, some cherry.  Finish is warm with cherry vanilla and oak.  This non-chill filtered bourbon is full of flavor.
Needed a strong pour for the final couple innings of the 2019 World Series. DD store pick.
I like the complex taste with spice up front but not into the alcohol burn,off tasting finish. Decent but I don't get the 95 rating.

Barrel #17-0152, Rickhouse B, Floor 6
The Silver Dollar pick.

Favorite Bourbon, so great!

Vanilla and cherries on the nose then honey on the palate. One of my favorite bourbons of all time. This was a PA Wine and Spirits barrel pick. They all differ in their own way but tons of vanilla in every pick. These never disappoint.

Strong nose with oak, corn, toffee, cinnamon, and a hint of leather. Sweet and spicy at first, with vanilla, cherry, and a hint of orange. Opens up to caramel, candied apples, almond, and warm oak. A lingering finish with oak, vanilla, and a touch of spice. Spicy and full bodied.
Woodland Wine Merchant Pick. Baking spices and lots of deep woody notes. So good.

My first Russell’s bourbon that I have tasted which I am digging!  Again can’t tell the nose due to cigars however the initial bite and after is wonderful.  Flavors are good.  Need to add this to the list!

I never want it not on my shelf. Lots of traditional and bold bourbon flavors with oak, vanilla, almond and some other sweet goodness that I can’t put my finger on but enjoy nonetheless. The proof is there, but in an enjoyable and not abrasive way.
Good Spirits "B-Day Banger" Warehouse F 10yr Pick.

I reviewed a pick from a different store a few months ago. This one is from Main Street Liquors in Nashville, TN.

The nose has cherry and apple fruit noses along with baking spices, rye, barrel char, leather and a hint of peanuts.

The palate has a medium body and is nice and spicy with rye and other baking spices, peanut dust and some subtle cooked fruit.

The finish is also spicy with some tingling in the back sides of the tongue and middle of the throat. I gets some nutty notes as the finish fades.

I like this pick. Compared to the other store pick I have, this one is spicier. Russel’s Reserve Single Barrels are very good, especially if you can snag a store pick.

So...as many of you are probably already aware of...store picks of RR can be dare I say...game changers. This particular pick is from Argonaut in Denver. We've had  few RR store picks drop this past year in Colorado, and this one is my favorite. 
Age: 9 years, 11 months
Nose: oh sweet nectar of the gods...nutmeg, allspice, caramel, vanilla 
Palate: Syrupy...the spice blends in perfectly with a cherry cordial cola thing. Oily af, and mouthcoating. Tingles the front of the tongue and gives way to the perfect hug. Goes on for a minute or two.
Finish: just alluded to that...the perfect finish. All of the flavors come together like the second side of Abbey Road. "And in the end, the love you take is equal to the love"...the Russells make.

Neat.  Neck pour.  Party Source 9 year pick.  Nose is incredible right off the bat.  Fruit forward.  Strawberries and apples.  Oak and caramel.  Vanilla.  Pie crust.  Hint of nuttiness.  It’s the fruits that are blowing me away tonight.  

Nice, oily texture.  Strawberries, apple with brown sugar all over the tongue.  Oh damn, that’s good.  Caramel blast transitions to vanilla and leaves you with the pie crust on the legs.  Legs last awhile and transition to a dry peanut.  That nutty note is becoming more and more predominant as time goes on.

What a great pour.  Best Russell’s Reserve pick I have had yet.  I might even put this in a blind flight of my favorite 2019 purchases.

Note: this was a neck pour with a couple drops of water, after first trying neat.

The nose after adding water, was sweet, all spice with cinnamon and vanilla.

The palate was a vanilla pie crust tasted with an oily texture followed with a spicy cinnamon.

The finish was spicy but pleasant and not much burn for a 110 proof.

In conclusion, after trying it neat, personally I found it to be very spicy from start to finish. After adding a few drops of water, I thought it brought out the great character of this bourbon and I see why it has such great reviews.
Wonderful bourbon
Smooth with a mildly spicy finish. Rich and vanilla. Smooth from beginning to end, preferred neat.
Close to a perfect bourbon. Apple and citrus notes. layers of sweet, spice, and earthiness. Leather, chocolate, and just enough burn to remind you this is whiskey.

Really good neat
Smooth
No burn

Strong alcohol on the nose, cherry bomb and then a bit of tongue tingle on the palate, long finish

(Tasted at Bourbon Bastards, 1/23/20)
Strong burn. Fire on the tounge.

Smells of nutmeg and molasses 
Tastes warm cinnamon and vanilla
After taste citrus
Most predominant nose was light oak and baked goods. I tasted the baked goods most on the back end. I think those flavors would be highlighted more if there was just a little less spice.

Color is beautiful golden amber. Legs are notably viscous. Nose is vanilla, butter, and bread with undertones of spice and dark fruits. Gaining complexity the longer I sit here smelling it. After a few minutes, the nose noticeably softened and opened up to the more delicate scents of pears and peaches. Initial palate is thick with a smooth burn. Subsequent sips result in a palate of chocolate, vanilla, and cinnamon; the spiciness perfectly balances out the sweetness to the point that neither are overpowering.  Much like the nose, the palate becomes more complex and new flavors jump out every sip: coffee, smoke, pepper, oak. The finish is smooth and deep, creating that pleasant warm feeling lasting well beyond the last sip. Overall, I love the complexity of this bourbon. I bought this bottle on sale specifically because I enjoyed their single barrel rye so much; I think this one might be even better. As I work my way up the ladder of nicer bourbons, this one currently sits on the top of the list.
Wood, leather, molasses, and vanilla with a slight chocolate finish
sweet, brown sugar, spice box.  Mellow but lingering heat.  Delicious!

Gordon's Private Barrel 
Barrel 0275
Rickhouse A 
Floor 4

Deep copper color. Nose has a lot of burnt caramel, Juicy Fruit chewing gum, cinnamon and browned butter. Mouthfeel is a little lighter than I would like, but not watery. Palate is hot and spicy with a lot of cinnamon and nutmeg, and a big up-front dose of oak tannins. It's quite grain-forward with very little sweetness driven by a little brown sugar toward the back end. Finish is medium-long, dry and oak-heavy.
Strong/ harsh up front.  Not a smooth taste
Vanilla nose.  Velvety smooth with bity finish.

RR “Brrdman” Store pick 9yr 3mo CNA Warehouse Floor 422-

Nose- Burnt graham crackers, cinnamon red hots, caramel, ethanol

Palate- Heavy toasted oak, Cinnamon, dark fruits, Vanilla spice

Finish- medium, heavy finish of overpowering oak

This barrel was picked on a -17• day. Picturing myself on a -17 degree day, this bourbon would be a slam dunk. Super warming and gives a hell of a kentucky hug. On a normal day though, this is about average. It’s nose is subdued with some bright notes, but has ethanol throughout. The palate is the opposite, big bold and in your face. Unfortunately, it has an overpowering flavor of oak. Hopefully as the bottle oxidizes, this will get more balanced and flavorful.
Love the spicy/vanilla combo in this bourbon, some heat comes first with a finish that includes some hints of cinnamon and baking spices, really enjoyed sipping this one
Readily available...affordable...better than Blantons SB in my opinion
Excellent nose and wonderful flavor. Spicy finish.

Lots of caramel and vanilla on nose and palate...and just the right amount of spice.  Probably the best bourbon that is readily available for a decent price.  I’m upgrading my score to 4.5 because I’ve had multiple bottles and none of them have disappointed.
A very bright bourbon... starting to grow on me

BACKGROUND: Russell’s Reserve Single Barrel first appeared on liquor store shelves in 2013, and the barrels used for bottling are touted as the hand-picked, cream-of-the-crop personally selected by Wild Turkey Master Distillers Jimmy and Eddie Russell from the center cut of the rickhouse.

Before being considered for selection, the bourbon is aged in the deepest number 4 or “alligator” charred American white oak barrels to ensure the richest flavor and color. 

Unlike many whiskies on the market, the bourbon in RRSB is also non-chill filtered.  Chill-filtration is a  common  process whereby the whiskey is chilled  at temperatures below freezing and is passed through an absorption filter, thus removing fatty acids and other flavor contributors such as esters and proteins.  By avoiding the chill-filtration process, the whiskey is bottled with more flavor compounds and a deeper color, which is denoted by an impressive haze when ice or chilled water is added.

It is interesting to note that Wild Turkey uses only one mashbill for its entire bourbon line - Wild Turkey 80, WT101, Rare Breed, Russell’s Reserve, Kentucky Spirit, and others - and the differences in flavors among expressions are almost entirely the result of aging and placement.

The lone bourbon mashbill consists of 75% corn, 13% rye, and 12% barley.  Its single rye mashbill is comprised of 51% rye, 37% corn, and 12% barley.
The 110 proof Russell’s Reserve Single Barrel retails for $60, which is about $20 more than the 90 proof Russell’s Reserve white label that carries a 10 year age statement. 

A special 114 proof Russell’s Reserve that was distilled in 2002 costs $250, but it is a bit of a unicorn as only 3,640 bottles were released.
 
NOSE: For a 110 proof bourbon, the nose is quite sweet, delicate, and reserved.  It offers oak (RRSB is rumored to be aged 8 to 9 years), orange peel, sugary vanilla cake frosting, and a good bit of corn.

PALATE: The palate starts with an alcohol bang from the get-go, and it is followed by loads of oak, cinnamon, dark cherry tartness, and the aforementioned vanilla frosting.  The experience is almost a seesaw of sweet and spice in alternating waves.  The viscosity is so delightfully thick that the bourbon is almost chewy.  

FINISH: The finish is long and warming and all of the flavors dissolve into a lingering rye mint.  A touch of oaky bitterness tickles the back of the throat.

FINAL ASSESSMENT:  This is not a beginner’s bourbon, but rather one that experienced bourbon aficionados will pull off of their shelf time and time again.  

When you consider that its standard WT101 expression, Rare Breed, Russell’s 10 Year, and this single barrel can all be purchased for $60 or less, Wild Turkey likely offers consumers among the best bottle-for-bottle return on investment of any distillery.

Plus…I think Jimmy Russell is one of the coolest sumbitches alive and kicking today.
Mild corn dust, butter, light sugar on the nose. Slightly oily, some cinnamon and an alcohol burn that stays mostly up front. Fair amount of spice that lingers, even after diluted a touch.
Vanilla, barrel char, cinnamon, orange peel
To be honest, I haven’t had a lot of different bourbons, but this is definitely one of my favorites so far. The spicy cinnamon and oaky vanilla complement each other nicely.
Not too much burn considering the high abv. Very interesting palate, more complex than the 10 yr but similar
A hint of sweetness leads into a mouthful of rich fruit and cake with a wonderful lingering spiciness
Vanilla, cherry and cinnamon. Nice long finish

Nose - cherry, apple, bubble gum, cinnamon, spearmint, allspice, caramel, light vanilla, oak notes, light/moderate ethanol burn. 

Taste - strong oak, cherry, caramel, vanilla, cinnamon, spearmint, allspice, apple, burnt brown sugar, cola, bubble gum, rye spice, moderate alcohol burn, finishing medium-length with brown sugar, caramel, and slightly minty flavors. 

Overall, it’s pretty good. Definitely better than the standard 10 year. However, I think the overpowering oak notes obscure some of the more nuanced beauty of the palate.
Nice mouthfeel. Nice amount of caramel flavor and subtle finish.
Good nose with a bit of cinnamon & oak coming through. Has a real kick to it at first and then a lovely vanilla/toffee taste
Super gentle and smooth for a bourbon. No tangy aftertaste.

Tried neat- wow, not expecting a pour this smooth. I'm inclined to say that it doesn't need any water or ice...

Tried on the rocks- not bad at all, definitely above average, but I think this bourbon is best enjoyed neat or with some water, depending on preference. Once the temperature dropped, I felt like it wasn't as smooth on the finish.

Tried with splash of water- I think that my first inclination was right. Neat or slightly diluted is the best way to enjoy this one

Bold bourbon flavors make this the most mouth-watering whiskey I've ever had.  There's more oak then I'm accustomed to.  (But I've heard that that is in line with what to expect from Wild Turkey.)  

I added water, and regretted it instantly.  Water does away with the viscosity - my favorite part - and leaves the mouth bone dry.  

Overall, a surprisingly different arrival and a memorable finish.  I'm going to let this sit in the bottle for a while and let it oxidize.  It may get better.
Really good pour, big bold flavors all around. The alcohol is present but not overpowering at all, I actually really enjoy it.
Excellent sipping Bourbon. Have enjoyed neat multiple times. The higher proof does not need water. Good vanilla on the nose, medium burn...recommend highly.
incredibly smooth and complex. tiny bit of spice in the finish. Love it
Dark brown color. Real smooth on the palette. A bit of burn on the back end settles for a leathery finish.
Nice aroma hints of vanilla and caramel. Smooth beginning very sweet on the tongue. Drops off evenly and smooth to a slight alcohol forward finish. Overall very nice.
Now this is nice. Great taste and smooth
A lot of times I don’t enjoy a whiskey the first time I taste it. This was not the case. It has a rich flavor with a high proof that is easy to drink.

This is a “Hot One”. 110 Proof, so this guy packs a punch.  I tried it neat and with a cube, and liked it with the cube better.  Opens up the nose and is bursting with Oak Flavor, doesn’t finish with a ton of alcohol flavor.   I liked it, not a daily drinker, but great for the nights you need to warm up.  Fireside style.
Solid with lots of flavor, but a little hot for me. Enjoyed it more as a fresh crack than once it started oxidizing.

Nose- candy corn- oak- vanilla - cinnamon- 
P- nutty / oak 
Finish - warm- medium length- not as much flavor 
Excellent whiskey- not premium- but great option
Nice mouth feel. A little warm nice caramel notes.
Very spicy at first, but has an oat taste similar to Greenspot and a fruitiness that is syrupy cherry. Finishes with a toasty spiciness.

Had the AJ’s Fine Foods Barrel Pick. It was Wonderful! Floor 5 warehouse F. 110 proof and drank like a 90. It was full bodied and fruit forward. Light banana notes on the finish and deep cherry on the nose. Going back to buy another bottle today

Aroma - Cinnamon Stick, Cherry, Honey, Vanilla
Texture - Full and Hot
Flavor - Baking Spices, Oak, Toffee, and Cinnamon Candies
Finish - Long with more Oak, Vanilla, Cherry and subtle Almond and Chocolate
easy on the pallet, not too complex
Store pick. Mild rye spice, vanilla, grain, mild cherry. Has some proof, but smooth enough to drink lower than proof

Barrel 13-0094/Rickhouse A/Floor 5/Southport NC ABC Store Pick

NOSE: Wild Turkey Funk is front and center. Dry Dusty Barn Wood, Straw, Dry Leather, and Vanilla. After a little time in the Glencairn, Orange Peel and Chocolate show up. There is a bit of heat present as well.
NEAT: Relatively Thick and Clingy. Sweet Oak up front, Vanilla, Orange Peel, and Black Pepper Tingle. The Oak becomes very Astringent on the back of the tongue. Big, gradually growing KY HUG with Bitter Oak and Light Vanilla coating the palate.
SPLASH: A little water really helps this one. Mouthfeel becomes almost creamy. The palate gets Cinnamon Discs hard candy, Salted Butter, and heightened Vanilla. The Heat and Astringency is dialed way back. The Cinnamon Candy lingers on the finish with Musty Oak. Much better.
VERDICT: I waited about a 1/4 of a bottle before reviewing this, and I'm glad I did. The first few pours were not to my liking. Some time open has really helped. This is another solid Wild Turkey bourbon. This barrel was a bit on the bitter side, but benefitted a great deal from a little water. Glad I added it to the collection.
Very complex. Sweet, hot, nutty, Woody all at the same time. Strong cinnamon and vanilla notes.
Solid middle of the road bourbon
Quick burn, but settles nicely into complex and rich flavor

Nose: caramel, nuts, vanilla, cherry, 
Palate: nuts, cinnamon, clove, vanilla, cherry, plum
Finish: long, black pepper, almost minty

Nose: Beautiful charred oak, vanilla, and buttered bread.  Hits of nutmeg, cocoa, clove, cinnamon, and molasses.  The rye in the mash bill is coming through beautifully, too, with rosemary, thyme, and maybe a touch of dill.  Banana, strawberry, and cherries.  For something at 110 proof, the nose is surprisingly gentle and approachable.

Palate: Classic - oak, brown sugar, and vanilla.  Baking spices from the nose come through, but presenting much more assertively.  Hershey's process cocoa, camphor.  Tannin is absolutely evident, both in taste and texture, but not overpowering.  Mouthfeel is medium-light.  Finish begins wish an excellent wash of mint, vanilla, black pepper, baking spices, chocolate, and rye spice.  The tannin swells up and most of the flavors start to fade, though the mint transforms into an almost wintergreen character.  A slightly creamy characteristic pokes in, and then everything slowly fades.  Very slowly.  There's some good oil content here, lending to a long finish.

Other notes: I keep saying it, Wild Turkey is turning out some excellent examples in the different categories they deal in.  Is this unusual or doing something different with the Bourbon template?  No.  But it does serve as a top-tier example of what the category is capable of when you refine and hone your distilling and maturation processes to a high degree.  This has high rebuy potential for me.

Color is a medium copper. Nose is initially cherry, almond and some light spice. Later this becomes more of a mint note. Flavor - Honey, biscuit, butterscotch & nutty on the finish. Slightly oily and buttered toast flavor comes later. Later added some drops of water and don't suggest doing that. Nose vanished and flavors muted. Prior to the water it was stellar.  Excellent
A bit hot but then cools off

On the nose I start with cinnamon then I get salty caramel. Don't breath too deep, the alcohol will take over. A hint of chocolate, then cinnamon and heat that lingers. This is nice. The Russell's clearly pick to a flavor profile. This is a lot like Kentucky Spirit but higher octane. The alcohol is more forward so ice helps bring out the flavors.
Neat.  Quick burn and smooth finish.  Nice spice and great vanilla cream finish.  Great value.
Wow. So smooth. Don’t drink with water, it’s too damn good to be tainted.
Brown sugar, vanilla and cinnamon on the nose and palate. Some alcohol burn early, but doesn’t linger on the back like Old Forester 1920.

Nose: light butterscotch, vanilla, oak, and baking spice
Palette: sweet on front then spice hit middle and long finish.  
This is an excellent bourbon!  Even adding water it stays delicious.  Highly recommend!

Gays Hops-N-Schnapps vol2 pick 1
Rick G 4-44-3

Nose: caramel, sweet cream, apple, hint of citrus, light ethanol for proof, vanilla 
Palate: candied oranges, oily glass mouthfeel, pound cake, oaky, apple
Finish: long and spicy, creamy, cinnamon, oak astringency

Nose: pretty modest,  but a sweet oaky scent is present.
Tons of flavor. A lot more oak than what I expected. Nice vanilla and caramel on the back end. Great warmth throughout that extends into the chest. Maintains smoothness however.
Outstanding. Rich with a long finish, slightly peppery on the way out. Just enough to enjoy it without being overpowered by it. Smooth despite the ABV.

This is a Binny’s Beverage Depot Store Pick. 

Sweet on the nose - caramel, vanilla. It’s a medium to full body feel. The palate comes with cinnamon and heat that fades to caramel, vanilla and coconut. The finish is long - starts with oak and fades back to the caramel, coconut, chocolates. Very good bourbon!

Light and classic nose. Floral with spice. Caramel and cherry. Brown sugar. Perfect mix of classic flavors and spice.

Round and rich. Complex but still light. Medium finish. 

I use the rating scale below. Distiller uses a scale of 5 and I use a scale of 10, but I’m sure you’re not too drunk to do the math! 

1. Disgusting - So bad I poured it out.
2. Poor - I wouldn't consume by choice.
3. Bad - Multiple flaws.
4. Below average - Not bad, but many things I'd rather have.
5. Good - Just average.
6. Very Good - Better than average.
7. Great - Well above average.
8. Excellent - In a league of its own.
9. Incredible - An all-time favorite.
10. Perfect

Hot up front with a ton of spice. Very full, rich and oily with a great mouth feel. Longer finish with and explosion of hot cinnamon, then huge Vanilla and a bit of cherry. Holds up well to ice, but really doesn't need it.
I can say it's worth every penny of it's $50 price tag.
This has  become my very favorite in the price range.
Very thick with a lot of flavor.
Talk about a rich bourbon! Wonderful spice and sweetness. Flavor for days. Typical bourbon flavor profile turned up to 11.
One of my new favorite bourbons.
Nice heavy vanilla before and after, sweet with some spices and smooth stuff, highly recommended!!
Complex sweetness with spice. Roller coaster of flavor. Loads of cinnamon. Single barrell select from liquor barn

This is from a local store in Hendersonville, TN (just outside Nashville) called Center Point Liquors. Warehouse B, 4th floor, 8 years and 6 months.

The nose is sweet with vanilla frosting, caramelized red apples and plumbs, raisins, rye and other baking spices, light chocolate, along with some wild turkey funk, which I describe as an empty peanut can with some dusty peanut debris, and there’s also a hint of baked bread. Very pleasant nose.

The palate is sweet and medium viscosity. It has rye spice, chocolate, caramel, vanilla frosting, a little bit of dried fruit and dusty peanut can.

The finish is long with cooked plumbs, corn, and a lingering rye spice on the back of the palate.

This is probably the best Russel’s Reserve Single Barrel store pick that I have had, and it was a neck pour! This one has all of the classic Wild Turkey profile notes that I love in spades.

I’ve heard a lot of good things about Russell’s Reserve Single Barrel but never thought to give it a try. Surely enough, my first experience did not disappoint. I tasted an expression from Barrel 19-0257/Rickhouse F/Floor 611. From the moment I began to pour this elixir into my Copita nosing glass I could smell the ethanol emanating from it which told me it was a high proof bourbon. Although bottled at 110 proof/55% ABV, it is very well balanced and rounded off with some delightful sweet notes. Russell’s Reserve Single Barrel is comprised of 75% corn, 13% rye and 12% malted barley then matured in number 4 “alligator” charred American White Oak barrels. This non-chilled filtered whiskey is hand-selected by Master Distillers Jimmy and Eddie Russell.

Color: Rose Copper

The tasting was superb starting with hints of burnt caramel, toffee, cloves, brown sugar, oak, cinnamon, and orange citrus notes on the nose. Following, on the palate were notes of oak, pepper, vanilla, cinnamon spice, nuts, baking spices, and some cherry fruitiness. The finish is long, slow, and warming with lingering pepper notes with oak and vanilla.
